APA Style Template for Research Papers (Google Docs-Ready)

Struggling to format your research paper in APA style using Google Docs? You're not alone. APA (American Psychological Association) style is the gold standard for formatting in the social sciences, yet many students and professionals still wrestle with the margins, headers, title pages, and citation rules. The good news? You don’t need Word to get it right — you just need a clear process, a reliable template, and a few insider tricks within Google Docs.

Why APA Style Still Matters

APA style goes far beyond just “looking right.” It ensures academic consistency, enhances readability, and gives proper credit to sources. If you're submitting to a journal, university, or academic institution, odds are high that APA 7th edition is the required format.

APA Style Is Required For:

  • Psychology, Sociology, Education, Nursing, and related disciplines
  • Formal research papers, case studies, and literature reviews
  • Student papers and professional publications alike

Step-by-Step: APA Formatting in Google Docs

You don’t need to start from scratch. Google Docs offers built-in tools, but you'll need to configure a few key elements. Here's how:

1. Set Up APA-Compliant Page Settings

  1. Margins: Go to File > Page setup. Set all margins to 1 inch.
  2. Font: Use 12-pt Times New Roman, Arial, or Calibri.
  3. Spacing: Select Format > Line & paragraph spacing > Double.
  4. Alignment: All text should be left-aligned (not justified).

2. Add a Running Head and Page Number

While APA 7 omits the "Running head:" label for student papers, professional papers may still include it.

  1. Click Insert > Headers & footers > Header.
  2. Type your paper title in all caps (flush left).
  3. Insert page number: Insert > Page numbers > Top of page (right).

3. Format the Title Page

APA student title pages require:

  • Paper title (bold, centered)
  • Author name
  • Institutional affiliation
  • Course name and number
  • Instructor’s name
  • Due date

All items should be centered and placed midway down the first page. Don’t forget the double spacing!

4. Organize the Main Body

Start the body on a new page after the title. Begin with the title again (bold, centered), then write your introduction without labeling it. Headings should follow APA style:

  1. Level 1: Centered, bold, title case
  2. Level 2: Left-aligned, bold, title case
  3. Level 3: Left-aligned, bold italics, title case

Use headings to break down your paper logically. Avoid unnecessary sublevels unless truly needed.

5. Create a Proper References Page

  1. Start on a new page.
  2. Center the word References (bold, not underlined).
  3. Alphabetize entries by the first author's last name.
  4. Use a hanging indent: Format > Align & indent > Indentation options > Hanging.

Bonus: Common APA Formatting Mistakes to Avoid

  • Using bold or italics incorrectly: Only headings and title are bolded.
  • Incorrect line spacing: Check spacing between paragraphs and titles.
  • Improper citations: Every in-text citation must match a References entry.
  • Wrong font or font size: APA allows a few choices — stick with one throughout.

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Can I use Google Docs to format a full APA paper?

A: Absolutely. Google Docs provides all the tools needed — headers, page numbers, font options, spacing, and even templates — to format a proper APA-style research paper.

Q: Is there an official APA template for Google Docs?

A: While APA.org provides Word-based templates, educators and institutions often share adapted versions for Google Docs. The template linked above is fully APA 7 compliant.

Q: Do I need a running head in APA 7?

A: Only professional papers require a running head. Student papers just need a page number in the top-right header.

Q: What citation tool should I use in Google Docs?

A: Go to Tools > Citations. Google Docs supports APA style and can auto-generate both in-text and full citations. Double-check for formatting accuracy.

Q: How do I create a hanging indent in Google Docs?

A: Highlight your references list, then go to Format > Align & indent > Indentation options and set the “Special indent” to “Hanging.”

Conclusion

Formatting an APA-style research paper in Google Docs doesn’t have to be a formatting nightmare. With the right setup — or better yet, a professionally formatted template — you can focus more on writing and less on spacing. Whether you’re a student or a pro, mastering APA in Google Docs is an essential academic skill.
